abstract.p: The last will and testament of Nicholas Thorne.

div.p:
Ã¾e The fourth day Auguste in the yere of oure lorde god a thousand fyvehunderth fourtie and sixe And in the
xxxviijti yere of the reigne of oure moste dredd soveraigne lorde harry the viijth by the
grace of god of Englande ffraunce and Irelonde king defendor of the faithe and in earthe
of the churche of Englande and also of Irlonde the supreme hedde
I Nicholas Thorne Citizen and merchaunte of the towne or Citie of Bristowe being in good
helthe and of perfite mynde and good Remembraunce god be thanked Remembring
the mutabilitie and uncertantie of this Transitory worlde / And most especiall the
casuall and soden deathe that doithe happen / And willing therfore for to make in a
ordynes my self do make and ordein this my present testament and last will in maner and
forme After folowing that is to saye I give and and bequeth my Soule unto
almyghtie god that created made and redemed me and all the worlde humblie beseching
him to take marcy uppon me and put me in his eternall glorie to the lawde and
prayse of hym / And of his moost and gloriouse blessed name / And my body to be buryed
yf I dye in bristowe in the churche of saynte warborewgh where my late wif Mary
Thorne lyeth buryed and at my buryeng be said and sing dirige . and masse withall
other dyvyne service as a true cristen men ought to have / And that at my burying
be spent and gyven to poore people not passing the Sume of xv li sterling I
will that xij poore men of the whiche viij of them to be duellers within the parishe
of saynt Nicholas and the other iij to be within the parrishe of sainte warborough
aforesaid that have byn housholders and fallen in decaye be geben to every of them
a gowne of mowster muster, i.e. muster-cloth - a mixed grey woolen cloth or Russett of the price of every gowne twentie shillinges sterling
And more to every of them xiijs iiijd in redy money I will above all thinges
my debtes be paid yf any appere that I do owe by wryting Score or by sufficyent
Recorde to any persone or personnes. I bequethe a monges the poore housholders
dwelling wtin within the Citie of bristowe aforesaid one hundred marces sterling to be
paid and delyvered to them wtin within one yere next after my burying I bequeth
to the Churche of saint Nicholas in bristowe aforesaid xl s sterling towardes
the reparacions and mayntenance of the clock and of the chyme in the said church
the whiche xl s to be paid and delivered by myne executors wtin within xij monthes
after my burying I bequethe to brother in lawe Willyam Harpar
a gowne Wherof the forparte is lyned wt with damask a Jacket of tawney damaske
a gowne furred wt with boge OED: Budge: `A kind of fur, consisting of lamb's skin with the wool dressed outwards.' a Jacket of tawney velvett a dublett of satten a
golde ring wt with tenne pounde in money / And to my Sister his wif a ring wt with a
dyamount diamond and more a ring wt with an esmyrall emerald and a ring wt with a ruby whiche is at
this daye in her keping my gowne of violet in grayne furred wt with boge and xl ounces
of silver and more to her tene poundes in money and to my brother her husbonde
and to her to gownes of the price lvj s iiij d And more to my Sister a small
Arres bedde I bequethe to ffraunces Woseley x li in salte after xx s the tone
And to Nicholas Woseley his brother twentie poundes in salte afte xx s the
onne to be paid and delyvered to them by myne executors wtin within xij monethes
after my buryall I bequethe unto vincent Thorne resident in Iane
two hundreth ducates and more the residue of the debte that the palabyzenes
genewys owethe unto me of the bequeste of my brother Robert Thorne
decessed / whiche debte I recon to be a boute two hunderth fyftie ducates the
whiche legace i wil be paid to for hym unto leonarde Caltaynes Genewys or
to his assigns And to be put in saynte Georges of Geane to and for thuse
behofe profett and advantage of the said Vincent Thorne / I will
that yf the said Vincent Thorne happen to dye before he come to thage of
xxj yeres, then I will that the same bequest be delyvered to the use and
behofe of the house of the bartilmews in bristowe aforesaid There to be
employed to the most advauntage that maye growe of and towardes the
buylding and Reperacyon of the same house or inpurchessing of lande for the
mayntenanc es of the free Schole there after the discrecion of myne executors
or there assignes or suche personnes that shall herafter have the charge of the
same house thinketh most nessessery for the behofe and mayntenance of the said
free Scole I will and bequethe unto Roberte Thorne being prentice
wt with Willyam Ostriche of london haberdasher one hunderth poundes sterling
I give and bequethe to Nicholas Thorne my bastard sonne nowe
being in Biskaye lxvj lili xiij ss iiij d d sterling And I will that he wtwith whome
the said Nicholas is printice to have the Rule and keping of the said
lxvj li xiij iiij d sterling for the terme of vij yeres fynding suffycient
Surties to the Chambre of bristowe for the assuraunce repayment and
delyvery of the said lxvj li li xiij ss iiij dd sterling at thende of the said vij
yeres And yf any syfficyente parson w tinwithin this towne or Citie of bristowe
suche as myne executors thinke sufficyente that will offre most to the
said Nicholas gyven sufficyente surties to te Chambre of bristowe
aforesaid that to hym I will be delyvered the said lxvj lili xiij ss iiij d d sterling
during the tyme of his apprenticchode / I give and bequeth unto
the Chambre of bristowe aforesaid one hunderth poundes sterling to be
employed in maner the bankes in the marshe in the said towne and
Citie of Bristowe where as it shalbe thought mooste nede Miscopied. The PCC will states: `Item I geve and bequeth unto the Chambr of Bristow aforesaide one hundreth poundes sterling to be employed in manner and forme following that is to say / tenne poundes thereof towardes the reperation of the bridge. And tenne poundes therof towardes the reparation and mending of the walles of the backe and the key / And for thw repairation and mayntenance of the bankes in the marshe in the saide towne and Cytie of Bristow Wheras it shalbe thought most neade.' And lxxx li
the rest and Residue of the said hunderth poundes sterling I will it
remayne towardes the making of a gro narde `Garnarde' in PCC to kepe suche provision of
corne as shalbe provyded for the comons of the said towne and citie of
bristowe / The whiche hundrethe poundes sterling I will that it be
employed expended and paid by the Advyse and ordre of my neighbr neighbor
John Drewes thelder To whome I bequeth xl li to be discounted and
deducted to hym of suche debtes as he dothe owe me at this presente day
As more larger do appere by his accompte made between hym and me thereof.
clerelye I releace and give to hym for the zeale love I beare to hym and for
his payne to see the said hunderth poundes so bestowed according to this my laste
will I bequethe to him a blacke gowne price xxx s s I bequethe towardes
the making of a damhede wt with Stone to the docke at the Key for the making and
repairing of shippes xxv lili sterling the same damhede to be made by the advyse
and counsell of Thomas Hickes and Edwarde Jones and to every of them for
there paynes taking thereof xx s sterling I bequethe to my cosen John
Thorne one of my skarlett gownes and one other gowne furred wt with bodge a Jackett
of damaske a Jackett and a doublett of velvett and a doublett of satten and more
to hym and to his wif two blacke gownes price liij ss iiij d d I geve and
and bequethe to master Harrys Scole Mr master of the free Scole at the Bartilmews
fyve markes sterling and a blake gowne price xxx s s for his paynes taking
hereafter to bring up youthe there in vertue to the pleasure of god And he to
have the same rombe room that he nowe Hathe for term of his lif seke and hole
And yf the landes of the said Bartelmewes may be herafter ymproved by any
meanes the rentes to be any more then it is at this present daye Then I will that
his wages be enlarged to twentie poundes by the yere I bequethe to
Thomas Clarke of Aller to John Sariannte Ussher of the grammerschole to John
Sare notary to Marten Affilde to Thomas Warden to William Cooke and to
ffraunces Coston to every of them thre tonne salte I bequethe to
twentie poore maydens of good name and fame dwelling wtin within the said Citie
of Bristow intendinge there to inhabite and dwell wtin within the said Citie one
hundrethe markes sterling that is to saye to every meide at the daye of her marriage
fyve markes sterlingg in maner and forme as folowethe that is to saye the furste
yere vj maydens and every yere after vij maydens at the day of there
marriage to be paide fyve markes sterling I confesse to have remayning in my
handes at this present day of the goodes of mastres Tonnell deceassed sixe
poundes of money leste to be occupied for the behofe of her daughter named
Jone the whiche I will be paid unto the saide Jone at her marryage / Also I
give unto my legittimate sonne Robert Thorne the younger one hundreth
markes sterling and one hunderth uunces of silver half gilte and half parcell
gilte And one seventhe parte of iij quarters parte of my householde stuf or the
value of it I give and bequethe unto my legittimate Sonne Nicholas
Thorne one hunderthe markes sterling and one hundreth unces of silver
half gilte and half parcell gilte and one vijth th parte of iij quarters parte
of my householde stuf or the value of it I give and bequethe unto
my legittimate Sonne Edward Thorne one hundrethe markes sterling
and one hunderthe unces of silver halfe gilte and half parcell gilte and one vijth th
parte of thre parte of my householde stufe or the value of it
I give and bequethe unto my legittimate sonne John Thorne one hunderth
markes sterling and one hunderth unces of silver half gilte and half parcell parcell
gilte and one vij parte of ij quarters parte of my housholdestuf or the value of it
I give and bequethe unto my legittimate daughter ffraunces Thorne two
hunderthe markes sterling and to hunderthe unces of Silver half gilte and half
parcell gilte and one vijth th parte of iij quarters partes of my housholdestuf or the value of it
I give and bequethe unto my legittimate daughter Mary Thorne two
hunderthe markes sterling and two hunderth unces of silver half gilte and half parcell
gilte and one vij parte of iij quarters partes of my housholdestuf or the value of it
I give and bequethe unto my legittimate daughter Brigett Thorne two
hunderthe markes sterling and two hunderth unces of silver half gilte and half parcell
gilte and one vij parte of iij quarters partes of housholdestuf or the value of it
I give and bequeth unto myne aforesaid iij doughters ffrances mary
bridgett the hole parte that maye apperteyne unto me of the Stock
being and remaynyng w thwith the company and the and the encreace therof if any then
happen to be in there handes for wood that I have Joyned w thwith Edwarde
pryn and others when the yeres is expired according to the agrement be
twyne then and me and the same bequest to be repartyd and equally devyded
among my said iij legittimate daughters at the day of their marages
yf any of them happen to dye before the daie of there marages Then I will
that the longest lyver of them to have and enyoye the parte of the other so
deceassed and yf my said daughters all happen to dye before the daie of
there maryages Then I will that my foure sonnes legittimate or the longest
lyver of them shall have and enyoye the premysses equally to be devyded
betwyne them I bequethe unto my iij legittimate sonnes Roberte
Nicholas Edwarde and John Thorne my hoole parte asmoche as to me
may apperteyne of right to have of the company that I have Joyned in
bristowe aforesaid that is to saye w thwith Thomas Shipman and others when the
yeres of promes and agrement betwyne them and me be expired and determy
ned al the profettes and advantages of the stocke that maye rise and growe
to my parte I will that it be reparted and devyded amonges my said iiij
legittimate sonnes by equall porcyons when they and every of them happen
to accomplishe the age of xxi yeres / And yf it happen any of them to
dye before the age of xxj yeres then I will that the parte of hym so
happenyng to dye to remayne to the overlyvers of them I give
and bequethe unto my wyf bridgett Thorne one hunderthe and fiftie
pounds sterling and one hunderith and fiftie tonne of salte of water mesure PCC quarter measure
And I give and bequethe more unto my said wif to the fynding of her house
for one yere after my deceasse fiftie poundes in money More unto her two
Hunderth and fiftie unces of silver plate half gilte and half parcell gilte
More the quarter parte of all my householdestuf or the value of it / Item more all suche
Juelles of golde silver perl [stones] Illegible, but 'stones' in PCC stringes as she hathe of me in her governaunce the better
ring wt with an esmyrell or Iuell or a greate prearle fashoned like an Ackorne a Iuell in
golde fashoned like a fenys phoenix? wt with a rubye and a hanging perle onely excepted whiche
iij peces I will and bequeth to my iij legittimate sonnes that is to say the beste ring
wtwith the esmyrell to Roberte Thorne my legittimate sonne the Iuell fashoned like
an acrorne I give and bequethe to Nicholas Thorne my legittimate sonne / And the
fenys w twith the ruby and hanging pearle I give and bequethe to Edwarde Thorne
my legittimate sonnes / The reste of suche Iuelles as remaynethe to her
governance and keping I bequethe and give to my said wif I bequethe to
my said wif for terme of her lyf the farm of Aller courte Aller, Somerset which I have and
holde by leace of the Erle of Huntington George Hastings, 1st Earl of Huntingdon (1488 - 1544) or Francis Hastings, 2nd Earl of Huntingdon (1514 - 1560)? for terme of certen yeres yet to come
paing to the said Erle xvij li xj s by the yere The whiche farme is nowe in
the ?terme of Thomas Clerke paing for the same xxix li vj s by the yere And after
the decease of my said wif The premysses to remayne to my legittimte sonnes
Roberte Thorne and his assignes. I give and bequeth unto my said
wyf Bridgett Thorne my house that I now dwell in in bristowe for terme
of her lyf And my garden w twith the Stable / yf she dwell and in habett in bristowe
aforesaid paing the yerely rente for the said garden and stable to the lordes of
the same I give to my Wifes iij daughters named alice Barbars and
Katherne to every of them xx tonne of Salte to be delyvered to my wyf to the use
and behof of her said iij daughters I give and bequethe to my legittimate
sonne John Thorne one hunderthe poundes sterling wchwhich master John myles of
hampton stande bounden by his obligacyon to pay to me as more at large aperith
in the same bonde Whiche hunderth poundes I will it be delyvered to the company
wtwith Thomas Shipman in bristowe aforesaid to the use and behohof of my said
childe And thencreace and advantage therof in like manner I will yf all
my legittimate sonnes Roberte Thorne, Nicholas Thorne, Edwarde Thorne and
John Thorne and my thre legittimate daughters ffrances Thorne mary thorne
and bridgett Thorne happen to dye before they accomplishe and come to there
lawfull ages or before they be married Then I will that all my bequestes
to them before bequethed shall remayne in maner and forme following that is
to say one thurde parte therof to ffraunces Woseley and to Nicholas Woseley
the children of my Sister Katheren abovewritten and to Roberte and to Nicholas my
baste sonnes or to the longest lyver of them I meane one thirde parte of all the
bequestes unto my said vij children wt with all the profettes and advantages that
may growe or apperteyne unto my vij children by there parte of Sowbours
of my goodes or by any other meanes I will the one thirde parte therof bereparted
and devided amonge them the seconde thirde paarte ne destributed and
bestowed uppon the house of the Bartilmews in bristowe aforesaid towardes
The buylding and purchasing of landes for the maynenance of the free Scole
therefore the bringing upp of youthe in vertue and goodnes the other
thirde paarte the rest and residue therof to the Chambre of bristowe towardes
the making and repearing of the bridge and the highe waies abowte the Citie
of bristowe aforesaid I will that my said vij Childern be under the rule
and governaunce of myne executors and to be in suche place or places wtwith suche
parsonne and parsons as myne executors shall thinke mooste expedient And there
to be maynteyned of the rentes yssues and profettes and advauntages of the same to
be towardes there charges till they come to there lawfull age And then the
same to be reparted and distributed amongest them by the discreccyon of myne
executors excepte the house I nowe dwell in sett in small strete in the
said Citie of bristowe the Whiche house I give and bequethe by this mylast
will and testament to Roberte Thorne my legittimate sonne when he
accomplishe the age of xxj yeres And to the heires of his body lawfully be
gotten / And for defaulte of suche yssue of his body lawfully begotten Then
I will that the said house wtwith his appurtenances to remayne to my legittimate sonne
Nicholas Thorne and to the heires of his body lawfully begotten and for default
of suche yssue of his body lawfully begotten then I will that the said house
wtwith his appurtenances to remayne to my sonne legittimate Edwarde Thorne and to
the heires of his body lawfully begotten And yf the said Edwarde then happen
to dye wtout without heires of his body lawfully begotten Then I will that the said house
wtwith his appurtenances to remayne to my legittimate sonne John Thorne and to the
heirs if his body lawfully be gotten and yf the said John Thorne then happen to
dye wtoute withoute heirs of his body lawfully begotten Then the same house wtwith his
appurtenances to be for my daughter ffraunces Thorne of her bodye lawfully
begotten And yfor defaulte of suche ysse of her body lawfully begotten Then
I will that the said house wtwith his appurtenances to remayne to my daughter Mary
Thorne and to the heirs of her body lawfully begotten And yf the said mary
Thorne happen to dy wtout without heirs of her body lawfully begotten Then I will
that the said house wtwith his appurtenances to remayne to Bridgett Thorne my
daughter and to her heires of her body lawfully begotten And if the said
Bridgett Thorne happen to dye wtoutwithout heire of her bodye lawfull begotten
Then I will that the said house wt with his appurtenances to Roberte
Thorne my bastarde sonne and to the heirs of his body lawfully begotten
And yf the said Roberte Thorne dye wtout without yssue of his body lawfully
begotten Then I will that myne Executors make or cause to be made the
said house wtwith his appurtenances sure to thuse of the Chambre of the said Citie of
bristowe as maye be devysed by lerned counsell according to the due order of the same
I will that the rentes yssues and profettes comyng and growing of my
forme of knowle whiche I have for terme of yeres of the dymcyse and graunte
of James Clyforde Esquier shalbe of and for the finding of my children
during there mynoritie And when they and every of them come to there lawfull
age or elles to mary Then I will the said ferm wtwith appurtenances holly to remayne
and come to my said sonnes Roberte Thorne Nicholas Edwarde Thorne and
John Thorne and to there assines also I give and bequethe to the
said Roberte Thorne Nicholas Thorne Edwarde Thorne and to John Thorne
and to there heirs all suche landes and tenementes whiche I have at this day
by leas for terme of yeres or by copyholde or otherwyse wtin within the said Citie
of bristowe and ellse where to be devyded amongest them by thedistruccyon of
myne executors as they thinke the mooste convenyent The house that I dwell in
onely reserved to my said sonne Robert Thorne I will that myne
executors procure to recover all that apperteyne to me of right of the bequestes of my
brother Roberte Thorne aswell that apperteyne Unto me by his testamente of the
Sobber of his goodes his will being performed according to the tenor tenor and true meanyng
of the testamente and laste will of the said Roberte or by any other meanes as heire
to my said brother on whose Soule and all xpenchristian soules god take mercy I
bequethe to the house of the bartilmews in bristowe afoesaid towardes the
mayntenances of the free Scole and to make a library in suche place as SrSir John Barloo
late deane of the dissolved house and colledge of Westbury of Trym John Drewes
and ffraunces Codrington of bristow aforesaide merchauntes shall thynke moste best
or metest wtin within the house of the said bartilmewes thirtie poundes sterling And more
I give and bequethe all suche bookes as I have meate for the sai liberay more
my Estrobobia Whiche is in the keping of John Sprynte poticary
